LanguageIntroActivity
Spacnish_dashboardActivity
La manzana es roja
The apple is red
Word Definition
The
La
Manzana
Apple
es
is
Roja
Red
Introduction_comprehension
Do you understand " La manzana es roja"?
Spanish (Español) is the second most spoken language in the world with over 400 million speakers
Spanish is the official language of 20 countries
Although Spanish uses the Latin alphabet like English, words are pronounced differently in Spanish than in English
Did You Know?
Pronunciation:
Let’s look at some pronunciation tips to help you get the perfect Spanish accent
Let’s look at ‘Español’
The letter ‘a’ is pronounced as ‘aa’ as in ‘father’
Did you notice the letter ‘ñ’ in Español? This letter is peculiar to Spanish It is pronounced as ‘ny’ like in ‘canyon’
Country
Nationality
Spain/España
Español, Española
México
Mexicano, Mexicana
Guatemala
Guatemalteco, Guatemalteca
Cuba
Cubano, Cubana
Nicaragua
Nicaragüense
Costa Rica
Costarricense
Did you notice that the ‘x’ in ‘mexicano’ is pronounced as ‘h’
While ‘x’ is usually pronounced as ‘x’ in ‘flexible’; it is pronounced as a throaty ‘h’ in the words México, Mexicano and Oaxaca (a state in Mexico)
Did you notice the symbol on ‘u’ in nicaragüense?
Did you notice the symbol on ‘u’ in nicaragüense?
‘gü’ when followed by another vowel like in ‘güe’, is pronounced like ‘Gw’ in Gwen (eg; nicaragüense -> nicaragwense)
Grammar Tips
Have you noticed that some nationalities have two different endings?
We use different endings for masculine (usually end with -o) and feminine objects (usually ends with -a)
Argentine = masculine | Argentina = feminine Argentinos = masculine, pl. | argentinas = feminine, pl. For plural form, we just add an ‘s’
Grammar Examples
Did you notice that ‘argentino’ is pronounced as ‘arhentino’? In Spanish, ‘g’ when followed by ‘e’ or ‘i’, is pronounced like a throaty ‘h’
Grammar tip:
You may have noticed that nationalities are not capitalized in Spanish (eg: argentino)?
That’s because in Spanish, although names of countries and cities are capitalized words derived from them (languages, nationalities) are not.
So while the ‘e’ in España will be capatilized, the ‘e’ in Español will not be
This marks the End of The Introduction Module, Are you ready for a Quiz ?
Moving on …

Great! So now you know some key pronunciation and grammar peculiarities! Remember these as they will help you understand the Spanish accent and the language Let’s now move on to some greetings in Spanish
Hi! -> ¡Hola!
Grammar tip: ¡Double exclamations!
Did you notice the inverted exclamation points with ¡Hola!?
Grammar tip: ¡Double exclamations! The upside-down or inverted exclamation ¡! points are unique to Spanish
Grammar tip: ¡Double exclamations! This is to ensure that when you’re reading, you can tell long before the end of a sentence whether you’re dealing with an exclamation!
Now, let’s look at Good morning!
Good = Buen day = día
Although ‘día’ literally translated to ‘day’, it is used as ‘morning’ in the greeting ‘good morning’
In Spanish, nouns take up either masculine or feminine gender, for example ‘Dia’ is masculine
The adjectives describing these nouns therefore also need to reflect the same gender
Since ‘Dia’ is masculine we will use the masculine for of ‘good’ Hence we will add an ‘-o’ at the end and make it ‘Bueno’
Did you notice?
Good = Bueno (singular, masculine form)
Grammar tip: Greeting such as ‘Good morning’ and ‘Good afternoon’ etc. always take up plural forms in Spanish. Hence, we add an ‘s’ after both ‘Bueno’ and ‘Día’: Good morning! = ¡Buenos días!
Good afternoon!/Good evening! -> ¡Buenas tardes! Good = Buena (singular, feminine) Afternoon = Tarde (singular form)
Good morning! = ¡Buenos días! (masculine) but Good afternoon! = ¡Buenas tardes! (feminine)
We learnt that adjectives take male and female forms depending on the gender of the subject Since días is masculine we used Buenos and tardes is feminine. Hence, we us Buenas.
So remember!
Good morning! = ¡Buenos días! Good afternoon! = ¡Buenas tardes!
Both días and tardes are plural, hence, an ‘s’ is added
Warning !! Exam Ahead !!
Throughout your lessons, you will be given cultural tips on the vocabulary and grammar you learn along the way to ensure that you can use what you learn in the real world.

Good afternoon! = ¡Buenas tardes! Is usually used from 3pm-7pm However, it is not really time bound, good afternoon is usually used from lunch time until it gets dark. Expect lunch hour to be around 2pm or 3pm!

Good night! -> ¡Buenas noches! Good = Buena (with singular, femine subjects) Noches is feminine and plural, hence, we use Buenas
Good night! = ¡Buenas noches! Just like in English where we often use ‘good night’ to bid farewell, ‘Buenas noches’ can also be used to bid farewell Remember! Noches is feminine and plural
Informally: just a smile and ¡Hola!, sometimes a handshake if it’s a bit more formal A light hug and a kiss or two are common for friends and family, especially among women
Informally: just a smile and ¡Hola!, sometimes a handshake if it’s a bit more formal A light hug and a kiss or two are common for friends and family, especially among women
Greeting norms: Generally, shaking hands is considered formal and is better suited for business meetings
Good morning = ¡Buenos días! (masculine) but
Good afternoon = ¡Buenas tardes! (feminine)
Adjectives take male and female forms depending on the gender of the subject
Since días is masculine we used Buenos and tardes is feminine, hence, we use Buenas
Do you remember?
We always use plural forms for greetings like
Good afternoon = ¡Buenas tardes!
Both días and tardes are plural hence an ‘s’ is added
The first greeting we will look at is ‘Welcome’ – used when welcoming someone to your house
The Spanish word for ‘welcome’ is a combination of two words
Welcome = Well+Coming / Arrival
Well = Bien
Coming / Arrival = Venido (for males)/ Venida (for females)
Welcome (welcoming someone to your house) -> Bienvenido (welcoming a male), Bienvenida (welcoming a female)
When welcoming a female, use Bienvenida
When welcoming a male, use Bienvenido
Remember, we end with ‘a’ for feminine forms and ‘o’ for masculine!
Welcome (welcoming someone to your house) -> Bienvenidos (group of males/mixed group), Bienvenidas (group of females)
Remember, we add an ‘s’ at the end for plural forms!
When welcoming a group of men/mixed group use Bienvenidos, When welcoming a group of women use Bienvenidas
Let’s not look at: Nice to meet you
Greetings: The common phrase for ‘Nice to meet you’ literally translate to ‘Much pleasure’ in Spanish
Much = Mucho | Pleasure = Gusto
Pronunciation tip:
Did you notice the pronunciation of ‘mucho’? We earlier learnt that ‘h’ is always silent in Spanish…
However, when combined with c it is pronounced as ‘ch’ as in ‘church’
Nice to meet you -> Mucho gusto (Literally: Much pleasure)
Mucho = Much | Gusto = Pleasure
Let’s now look at how we will say ‘sorry’ in Spanish…
Greetings:
Sorry -> Lo siento
Let’s move forward and look at how we say ‘excuse me’ in Spanish…
Just like in English, excuse me may be used for two purposes – either to beg pardon or to seek someone’s attention…
Excuse me (begging pardon) -> Perdón
Excuse me! (seeking attention) -> ¡Discúlpeme!
¡Discúlpeme! Is pronounced as Dee-skool-pe-me. With the sound of ‘pe’ like in ‘pet’ and ‘me’ like in ‘met’
Let’s now look at ‘please’
Please -> Por favor
Por = For
Favor = Favour
Literally: Asking for a favor
Greetings: Thank you -> Gracias
Pronunciation tip: There’s a key difference in how ‘Gracias’ is pronounced in European Spanish vs. Latin American Spanish
‘C’ when followed by e/i is pronounced as ‘the/thi’ in European Spanish and ‘se/si’ in Latin American Spanish
Pronunciation tip: Hence we will say ‘Gra-thee-as’ in European Spanish and ‘Gra-see-as’ in Latin American Spanish
Let’s now look at ‘Fine, Thank you’. ‘Fine’ translates to ‘Bien’ in Spanish
Fine, Thank you -> Bien, Gracias
Bien = Fine/Well
Pronunciation tip:
Again, we say ‘Bien, Gra-thee-as’ in Europe and ‘Bien, Gra-see-as’ in Latin America
Now that you know how to say ‘thank you’ let’s also look at how we reply to ‘thank you’
In Spanish, ‘You’re welcome’ literally translates to ‘It’s nothing’ or
‘Of nothing’ loosely meaning ‘Don’t thank me for anything’: Of = De, Nothing = Nada
You’re welcome (reply to thank you) -> De nada: De = Of, Nada = Nothing
Literally: ‘it’s nothing’ / ‘of nothing’ | Meaning ‘don’t thank me for anything’
Let’s now look at the final greeting: Bye!
Bye! -> ¡Adiós! Also translated as ‘¡Hasta luego!’ which means ‘Until then!’
Pronunciation tip:
Did you notice the accent on the ‘ó’ in ¡Adiós!
If a word is marked with an accent, then that syllable receives the stress
An informal alternative to ¡Adiós! In many areas is ¡Chau!
Some English subtleties/polite words are not as widely used in Spanish
This may make the language sound brash at fist – but that’s not really true
Eg: You may notice that ‘por favor’ isn’t as widely used as ‘please’ in English
Instead of adding extra words (like por favor), we just turn a request into a question and it’’s considered just as polite
Eg: ¿Abres la ventana? : (Can) you (please) open the window?
Although we don’t really translate the ‘please’
Did you notice?
As we saw with ¡!, did you notice the ¿? In ¿Abres la ventana? In Spanish all questions start with a ‘¿’ and end with a ‘?’
The ‘¿’ is used to communicate the tone of the statement (question tone) in the beginning itself
For learning useful and interesting conversations in Spanish:
it is essential that we learn some basics which will help us with conversations in the future
In this lesson we will look at personal pronouns (like I, she, he, you etc.) and their forms in Spanish –
these would act as a foundation for us to move on to conversational lessons
Let’s start with ‘I’ and its plural form ‘we’
Pronunciation tip:
The ‘y’ in ‘Yo’ is pronounced like the English ‘y’ in some areas, sounding just as it would in English
While in others, it takes up the sound of the English letter ‘j’
Pronunciation tip:
Did you notice the pronunciation of ‘Ella’?
In Spanish ‘ll’ takes up the sound of ‘y’ in some areas and a soft ‘j’ in others
So you’ll hear both ‘e-yah’ and ‘e-jah’
Which pronoun would you use?
Ana (Noun) -> Ella (She) (Correct pronoun)
Which pronoun would you use?
Ana y Luis (Ana and Luis) (Noun) -> Ellos (Them, mixed group) (Correct Pronoun)
Grammar tip:
Did you notice the letter ‘y’ in Ana y Luis?
‘y’ = and
‘y’ is pronounced same as the sound of the letter ‘e’ in English
Which pronoun would you use?
José, Luis y Mark (José, Luis and Mark) (Noun) -> Ellos (Them, male group) (Correct pronoun)
Pronunciation tip:
José is pronounced ‘H-osay’ with a stress on ‘e’ (as it is accented) almost sounding like the ‘ei’ in eight
The letter ‘J’ sounds like ‘H’ in Spanish
Which pronoun would you use?
Ana y María (Ana and María) (Noun) -> Ellas (Them, girls group) (Correct Pronoun)
Which pronoun would you use?
María y tú (María and You (inf.)) (Noun) -> Vosotras/os (You, pl., informal) (Correct Pronoun)
Did you notice?
María y tú -> Vosotras/os
We put the right option as ‘vosotras’ or ‘vosotros’ because ‘tú’ is informal
Use of ‘vosotros’ or ‘vosotras’ will depend on the gender of the group
If it is all females we will use ‘vosotras’, otherwise we will use ‘vosotros’
Which pronoun would you use?
María y usted (María and You(for.)) (Noun) -> Usteded (You, formal) (Correct pronoun)
So remember!
María y usted as a group would be treated formally because ‘usted’ is formal
Hence they are together referred to as ‘Ustedes’
In Spain and Argentina, the informal forms tú or vosotros/as are used more often instead of the formal forms like usted
Although the formal forms are commonly used in Latin America
Usually, the singular informal tú is used when speaking with family members, children, friends or close acquaintances
While usted is used otherwise
If you’re uncertain which one to use, it is usually better to use usted
Unless the other person starts speaking to you using tú
In which case it is usually OK to reciprocate
¿Le puedo tutear? (Can I address informally with tú?) is often used to seek permission to start using tú
False friends, falsos amigos, are words which look or sound similar in two different languages but actually mean something else
For example, if you’re embarrassed, you may feel tempted to say embarazado (man)
Or embarazada (woman) because they sound so similar to the word
‘embarrassed’ …
However, that actually means I’m pregnant.
The right phrase to say is me da vergüenza
